title: The Eisenhower matrix: understanding task management

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the Eisenhower Matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: To prioritize tasks based on their complexity.

options.label: B
options.text: To categorize tasks based on their urgency and importance.

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate tasks that are not essential to one's life and career.

options.label: D
options.text: To delegate tasks to others.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the first quadrant in the Eisenhower Matrix, which includes tasks that are both important and urgent?

options.label: A
options.text: Schedule Sector

options.label: B
options.text: Delegate Sector

options.label: C
options.text: Do First Sector

options.label: D
options.text: Eliminate Sector

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a task that should be listed in the Schedule Sector of the Eisenhower Matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: A review of an important document for your manager.

options.label: B
options.text: A long-planned return to the gym.

options.label: C
options.text: A delegated task that needs to be checked on later.

options.label: D
options.text: A task that is not essential to one's life and career.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Eliminate Sector in the Eisenhower Matrix?

options.label: A
options.text: To prioritize tasks based on their urgency and importance.

options.label: B
options.text: To eliminate tasks that are not essential to one's life and career.

options.label: C
options.text: To delegate tasks to others.

options.label: D
options.text: To categorize tasks based on their complexity.

multiple-choice.question: According to Dwight Eisenhower, what is important is seldom urgent, and what is urgent is seldom important. What does this statement suggest?

options.label: A
options.text: That tasks should be prioritized based on their complexity.

options.label: B
options.text: That tasks should be prioritized based on their urgency and importance.

options.label: C
options.text: That tasks should be eliminated if they are not essential to one's life and career.

options.label: D
options.text: That tasks should be delegated to others.

title: RNAi: Slicing, dicing and serving your cells - Alex Dainis

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of RNA in a cell?

options.label: A
options.text: To act as a messenger between the cell's DNA and ribosome.

options.label: B
options.text: To move in reverse and create DNA.

options.label: C
options.text: To direct amino acids to their targets.

options.label: D
options.text: To take part in RNA interference (RNAi).

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of RNAi in a cell?

options.label: A
options.text: To ensure that all messenger RNA is turned into protein.

options.label: B
options.text: To prevent the cell from turning some messenger RNA into protein.

options.label: C
options.text: To destroy RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus.

options.label: D
options.text: To create double-stranded RNA molecules.

multiple-choice.question: What is the function of the slicer protein in the RNA Silencing Complex (RISC)?

options.label: A
options.text: To target matching mRNA.

options.label: B
options.text: To chop long, double-stranded RNA molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: To strip short snippets of RNA in half.

options.label: D
options.text: To slice up matching mRNA.

multiple-choice.question: How did scientists first discover the process of RNAi?

options.label: A
options.text: By studying humans.

options.label: B
options.text: By studying petunias and introducing a pigment-producing gene.

options.label: C
options.text: By studying C. elegans worms.

options.label: D
options.text: By studying RNA directly.

multiple-choice.question: What is one potential therapeutic application of RNAi?

options.label: A
options.text: Targeting RNA and tumor cells to turn off cancer-causing genes.

options.label: B
options.text: Creating double-stranded RNA molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: Destroying RNA injected into the cell by an attacking virus.

options.label: D
options.text: Preventing the cell from turning some messenger RNA into protein.

multiple-choice.question: D: To take part in RNA interference (RNAi).
B: To prevent the cell from turning some messenger RNA into protein.
D: To slice up matching mRNA.
B: By studying petunias and introducing a pigment-producing gene.
A: Targeting RNA and tumor cells to turn off cancer-causing genes.

title: Math jokes explained

multiple-choice.question: What is the joke about the "10 types of people in the world" based on?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference in the way people understand binary and hexadecimal.

options.label: B
options.text: The difference in the way people understand base 3 and base 10.

options.label: C
options.text: The difference in the way people understand binary and base 3.

options.label: D
options.text: The difference in the way people understand hexadecimal and base 10.

multiple-choice.question: What does the joke "10 in base b equals b in base 10" imply?

options.label: A
options.text: That there are only two types of people in the world.

options.label: B
options.text: That the joke can be generalized to any base.

options.label: C
options.text: That the number 10 has a different meaning in different bases.

options.label: D
options.text: That the joke is only funny in base 10.

options.label: A
options.text: That October 31st equals December 25th.

options.label: B
options.text: That October equals December.

options.label: C
options.text: That October 31st equals December 25th in base 8.

options.label: D
options.text: That October equals December.

options.label: A
options.text: October.

options.label: B
options.text: The eighth thing.

options.label: C
options.text: October 31st.

options.label: D
options.text: December.

multiple-choice.question: Why do mathematicians confuse Halloween and Christmas according to the joke?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of the similarity in the names of the months.

options.label: B
options.text: Because October 31st equals December 25th in base 8.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the difference in the way people understand binary and hexadecimal.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the difference in the way people understand base 3 and base 10.

title: Why do we have to wear sunscreen? - Kevin P. Boyd

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary purpose of sunscreen?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To promote skin tanning.

options.label: B
options.text: Physical and chemical blockers, and broad-spectrum and narrow-spectrum.

options.label: C
options.text: Physical and chemical blockers.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: UVA rays cause skin to age, while UVB rays cause skin to burn.

options.label: C
options.text: UVA rays are absorbed by the skin, while UVB rays are reflected.

options.label: D
options.text: UVA rays are reflected by the skin, while UVB rays are absorbed.
